metadata.title: Uptake of pantoprazole drug residue fromwater using novel synthesized composite iron nano adsorbent

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Molecular Liquids
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /mol l iq
Uptake of pantoprazole drug residue fromwater using novel synthesized composite iron nano adsorbent
Imran Ali a,⁎, Zeid A. AL-Othman b, Omar M.L. Alharbi c a Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia (Central University), New Delhi 110025, India b Department of Chemistry, College of Science, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia c Biology Department, Faculty of Sciences, Taibah University, P.O. Box 30002, Madinah Al-Munawarah 41477, Saudi Arabia
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: drimran.chiral@gmail.com, drimran
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2016.02.088 0167-7322/© 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 13 February 2016 Accepted 27 February 2016 Available online xxxx
Pantoprazole drug residue is present in some water bodies leading to toxicity to human beings. The uptake of pantoprazole drug residue from water is reported on composite iron nano adsorbent. Adsorbent was prepared by green method and characterized by FTIR, XRD, SEM, TEM and EDX techniques. The pantoprazole concentrations in adsorption experiments were determined by HPLC on new generation Sunshell C18 column (150 × 4.61 mm; 2.6 μm). The optimized parameters were 30.0 min., 50 μg L−1, 7.0, 1.0 g L−1, and 25.0 °C as contact time, concentration, pH, adsorbent amounts and temperature. The data obeyed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin–Radushkevich isotherms. ΔG° values were −9.53, −9.57 and −9.62 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures. ΔH° and ΔS° values were−3.39 and 20.19 × 10−3. These magnitudes showed favorable and exothermic adsorption. Pseudo-first-order and liquid film diffusion mechanisms of the adsorption were reported. The reported adsorptionmethodwas fast, environmental friendly and low-priced due to its nature to be applicable under natural conditions of water resources. The developed method may be applicable for the removal of pantoprazole drug residue in natural water resources at pH 7.0 with low amount of adsorbent and contact time. The adsorption method may be used for pantoprazole removal from any water body at large and economic scale.
© 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
Keywords: Pantoprazole Adsorption Modeling Kinetics and thermodynamics Water treatment Composite iron nano adsorbent

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, water contamination by drug residues is a serious concern. The drug residues present inwater enter into our body and disturb several biological activities. The most important effecting biological activities are hormonal, enzymatic and genetic [1]. Pantoprazole is among top twenty selling drugs in the world under various trade names. This drug is used to treat stomach and esophagus problems such as acid reflux and damage to the esophagus. It is also used for the treatment of Zollinger–Ellison syndrome [2]. Besides, this drug is also prescribed frequently in combination therapy with antibiotics, profens and others; to avoid the digestive system problems [3]. In this way, the rate of consumption of pantoprazole is quite high worldwide. It is very important to mention here that pantoprazole has also several side effects. The severe side effects include uneven heart beats, muscle
_ali@yahoo.com (I. Ali).
cramps, muscle weakness, limp feeling, feeling jittery, diarrhea, cough or choking feeling, memory problems, confusion, headache, loss of appetite, weight changes, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, drowsiness, joint pain and fracture and insomnia [4,5]. Besides, long term use of this drug results in hypomagnesia, osteoporosis, bone fracture and poor absorption of vitamin B-12, ampicillin esters, ketoconazole, atazanavir, iron salts, mycophenolate moftetil and certain minerals. Moreover, long term use of pantoprazole has sown carcinogenic and gastrointestinal tumors in rodents [6–12].
It is worthy to mention here that pantoprazole is contaminating our water resources. This drug residue has been reported at Granada city metropolitan areas, South of Spain [13]. Besides, this drug residue has been found in other water bodies at different places of the world [14–16]. Therefore, the removal of pantoprazole drug residue from water is demanding in thepresent scenario. It is important to emphasize that there is no method available for the removal of pantoprazole from water. Among many removal methods, adsorption is considered as the best one due to its many characteristic features [17–20]. Presently,
nano adsorbents are supposed as the best one owing to their unique features of adsorption.Moreover, these adsorbents have good capacities to adsorb different contaminants [21]. Therefore, the attempts were made to prepare and characterize composite iron nano adsorbent for the uptake of pantoprazole drug residue from water. The results are described in this article.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and reagents
sections.text: All the chemicals and reagents used were of HPLC and A.R. grades. Acetonitrile, methanol, 2-propranolol, ethanol, triethylamine, acetic acid and n-hexane were supplied by Merck, Mumbai, India. Black tea was collected from local market. Ferrous sulfate, carboxymethyl and cellulose epichlorohydrin were supplied by Qualigens Mumbai, India. Millipore water was collected from Millipore-Q, Bedford, MA, USA system. Pantoprazole standard was obtained from Sigma Aldrich Co., USA. Polypropylene membrane (pore size 0.1 μm) was supplied by GVS Filtration Technology, Italy.

sections.heading: 2.2. Instruments
sections.text: All the experiments were carried out on thermostatic water bath shaker and magnetic stirrer. The concentrations of pantoprazole were determined by HPLC system of Shimadzu (Japan) having solvent delivery pump (LC-10 AT VP), manual injector, UV–VIS detector (SPD-10 A) with system controller (SCL-10AVP ver 5.33) and Class VP software. New generation Sunshell C18 (150 × 4.61 mm; 2.6 μm) column was of Chromanik, Japan. As well, other equipments were sonicator, digital pH meter, centrifuge machine, weighing balance, UV–Visible spectrophotometer.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of composite iron nanocomposite adsorbent
2.3.1. Biosynthesis of iron nanoparticles by green method
sections.text: Black tea (30.0 g) was heated with 500 mL water at 80 °C for 1 h. After cooling, it was filtered using Whatman no. 1 filter paper. Tea extract was mixed with 100 mM ferrous sulfate solution (2:1, v/v) with continuous shaking for 1 h. The color from faint yellow to blackish brown was seen; indicative of iron nanoparticles formation. Ion nanoparticles were separated by centrifugation followed by washing with water. These were dried in air and rehabilitated into powder form.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Preparation of composite iron nano adsorbent
sections.text: Iron nanoparticles (1.0 g) were mixed with epichlorohydrin (1.5 mL) and 20% acetic acid (20 mL). The mixture was shaken for 24 h with addition of carboxymethylcellulose (CMC) (1.0 g) with continuous stirring for 5min. Reactionwas carried out for 24 h. The product was dried at 60 °C.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Characterization of composite iron nano adsorbent
sections.text: The prepared composite iron nano adsorbent was characterized by FTIR, XRD, TEM, SEM and EDX methods.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Preparation of pantoprazole solution
sections.text: Pantoprazole solutions were prepared of 10–70 μg L−1 concentrations. The solutions for HPLC analysis were prepared of 1–10 μg L−1 concentrations.

sections.heading: 2.3.5. Adsorption studies
sections.text:
The batch mode was carried out in thermostatic water bath shaker. The composite iron nano particles were separated by centrifugation. HPLC was used to determine the equilibrium concentrations of pantoprazole. Adsorption isotherms were carried out at 10–70 μg L−1 concentrations, 5–60 min. Contact time, 0.1–2.0 g L−1 dose, 3–9 pHs
and 20.0–30.0 °C temperatures. Thermodynamics and kinetics parameters were determined by the different models. Equilibrium concentrations of pantoprazole were calculated using the following formula.
Ce ¼ Ci−Ctð Þ=m ð1Þ
where, Ci, Ct, Ce and m are the initial, at time (t) and equilibrium amounts (μg L−1) of pantoprazole and weight of adsorbent (g L−1). The percentage removals of pantoprazole were determined by the following equation.
%Removal ¼ Ci−Ctð Þ=C0½ 100 ð2Þ
where, Ci and Ct show the usual meanings.

sections.heading: 2.3.6. Kinetics studies
sections.text: The kinetics study of pantoprazole was completed by uptake at various time periods. The various concentrations of pantoprazole were shakenwith exact amount of composite iron nano adsorbent till equilibrium achieved. Remaining pantoprazole wasmonitored by HPLC. Erlenmeyer flasks (100.0 mL) with exact and known concentrations of pantoprazole were shaken on thermostatic water bath shaker. The solutions were centrifuged and the supernatants were determined for pantoprazole. The blank experiments were done for the determination of the experimental errors.

sections.heading: 2.3.7. HPLC analysis
sections.text: The various amounts of pantoprazole were analyzed by HPLC as described above. The separation was ascertained using new generation Sunshell C18 (150 × 4.61 mm; 2.6 μm) column. The solvent system was acetonitrile:phosphate buffer (10 mM, pH 7.0) (30:70, v/v) at 1.0 mL min−1 flow rate (detection at 220 nm). The solvent system was filtered and degassed every day before application. Chromatographic parameters viz. capacity (k), separation (α) and resolution (Rs) factors were calculated using general HPLC equations.

sections.heading: 3.1. Biosynthesis of iron nanoparticles using tea extract
sections.text: Iron nanoparticles were prepared by green methods [22,23]. The polyphenol and caffeine molecules present in tea extract have antioxidant properties. These acted as capping and reducing molecules. Iron nanoparticles [Fe(II) to Fe(0)] were prepared with 90% yield.

sections.heading: 3.2. Preparation of composite iron nano adsorbent
sections.text: The composite iron nano adsorbent was synthesized from iron nanoparticles and carboxymethyl cellulose using epichlorohydrin as cross linker. The composite iron nano adsorbent was having 90% yield. First of all, epichlorohydrin had reacted with iron nanoparticles given that chloro functional group for additional reactionwith carboxymethyl cellulose. Oxygen group of carboxymethyl cellulose had reacted with chloro group of epichlorohydrin; following composite iron nano adsorbent.

sections.heading: 3.3. Characterization
sections.text:
The synthesized composite iron nano sorbent was characterized by FTIR, XRD, TEM, and SEM–EDX methods. The results are described herein.
FT-IR was used to ascertain the functional group of composite iron nano adsorbent. The peaks were in the range of 4000 to 400 cm−1. The wave numbers 3460 cm−1 and 1637 cm−1 corresponded to hydroxyl and ketonic groups. Wave numbers 1058 cm−1 corresponded the turnout of an alcoholic C–O stretching. These results established the
configuration of composite iron nano adsorbent. The peaks of 18.5 and 44.9 (at 2θ values) of XRD analysis of composite iron nano adsorbent indicated the presence of FeOOH and Fe0 (zero valent iron). XRD results also defined amorphous character of composite iron nano adsorbent.
SEM analysis was done to find out the surface morphology of composite iron nano adsorbent. SEM images of composite iron nano adsorbent are given in Fig. 1a and b (at different magnifications). SEM images had been recorded at 5000 and 15,000magnifications. Themorphological, topographical and crystalline structureswere determined by TEM analysis. TEM analysis results are given in Fig. 2a and b at 10,000 K magnification; presenting the morphology and single particle size. Morphology of composite iron nano adsorbent was flat. Also, it can be pragmatic from this figure that composite iron nanoparticles had size from 13.7 to 90.3 nm. Elemental composition of composite iron nano sorbent was done by EDX method. This figure obviously indicates the turnout of chlorine, oxygen, carbon, sodium and iron in the composite iron nano adsorbent. The appearance of gold element in spectrum was because of the samples that were coated with gold previous to analysis.

sections.heading: 3.4. HPLC analysis
sections.text: The equilibrium concentration of pantoprazole was ascertained by qualitative and quantitative analyses as per the standard protocol [24]. The retention time was 4.0 min.

sections.heading: 3.5. Optimization of adsorption
sections.text: The adsorption of pantoprazole drug residue was optimized by varying concentration, pH, dosage, contact time and temperature. The results of these changes are given in the following pages.

sections.heading: 3.5.1. Concentration
sections.text: For the optimization of concentration, the valueswere changed from 10 to 7 μg L−1. The other variables applied were 7.0 pH, 30 min contact time, 1.0 g L−1 dose and 25 °C temperature. The conclusion of this process is shown in Fig. 3a. An assessment of this figure shows sorptions 10, 20, 28, 36.5 and 44.5 μg g−1 at 10, 20, 30, 40 and 50 μg L−1 concentrations. Additional raise in concentration up to 70 μg L−1 could not improved sorption. Consequently, 50 μg L−1 concentration was selected for the optimization of the remaining parameters.

sections.heading: 3.5.2. Contact time
sections.text: For the optimization of contact time, the valueswere changed from5 to 60min. The other variables applied used were 1.0 g L−1 dose, 7.0 pH, 50 μg L−1 concentration, and 25 °C temperature. The conclusion of this process is shown in Fig. 3b. An assessment of this figure shows sorptions 20, 25, 35 and 44.5 at 5, 10, 20 and 30 min. Additional raise in contact could not improved sorption. Consequently, 30 min contact time was selected for the optimization of the remaining parameters.

sections.heading: 3.5.3. pH
sections.text:
For the optimization of pH, the valueswere changed from 3 to 9. The other variables applied were 50 μg L−1 concentration, 30 min contact time, 1.0 g L−1 dose, and 25 °C temperature. The conclusion of this
process is shown in Fig. 3c. An assessment of this figure shows sorptions 20, 30, 38, 42 and 44.5 at 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 pHs. Additional raise in pH could not improved sorption. Consequently, 7.0 pH was selected for the optimization of the remaining parameters.

sections.heading: 3.5.4. Dosage
sections.text: For the optimization of dose, the values were changed from 0.1 to 2.0 g L−1. The other variables applied were 50 μg L−1 concentration, 30 min contact time, 7.0 pH and 25 °C temperature. The conclusion of this process is shown in Fig. 3d. An assessment of this figure shows the adsorptions 20, 30, 42 and 44.5 at 0.1, 0.25, 0.5 and 1.0 g L−1. Additional raise in dose could not improved sorption. Therefore, dose was chosen for the rest of the experiments. Consequently, 1.0 g L−1 was selected for the optimization of the remaining parameters.

sections.heading: 3.5.5. Temperature
sections.text: For the optimization of temperature, the values were changed from 25 to 30 °C. The other variables applied were 50 μg L−1 concentration, 7.0 pH, 30 min contact time and 1.0 g L−1 dose. The conclusion of this process is shown in Fig. 3e. An assessment of this figure shows that the adsorption was same at all the three temperatures for 10, 20 and 30 μg L−1 concentrations. Adsorption was going to decrease on rising temperature. The adsorption order was 20 N 25 N 30 °C.

sections.heading: 3.6. Modeling of adsorption
sections.text:
The sorption of pantoprazole was calculated by Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin–Radushkevich models at 20, 25, 30 °C temperatures. The equations used are –
Langmuir.
1=Qt ¼ 1=XmbCt þ 1=Xm: ð3Þ
Dimensionless constants or separation factor (RL).
RL ¼ 1= 1þ bCeð Þ ð4Þ
Freundlich.
logQt ¼ 1=nð Þ logCt þ logkF ð5Þ
Temkin.
Qt ¼ RT=BTð ÞlnCtþ RT=BTð ÞlnKT ð6Þ
Dubinin–Radushkevich.
lnQt ¼ lnqm–βε2 ð7Þ
ε ¼ RTln 1þ 1=Ctð Þ ð8Þ
E ¼ 1=√ −2βð Þ: ð9Þ
Ct and Qt are concentration and amount sorbed of pantoprazole at t time. Xm (μg g−1) and b (L μg−1) are the constants of Langmuir model. The values of Xm and bwere computed by slope and intercept of plot of 1/Qt vs 1/Ct (Fig. 4a). Langmuir model explained the data exactly. These constants are given in Table 1. These values established the application of Langmuir isotherm. The values of Langmuir constant Xm (μg g−1) were 50.0, 47.62 and 45.46 at 20, 25 and 30 °C, temperatures. The b constant values (L μg−1) were 1.18, 0.76 and 0.68 at 20, 25 and 30 °C, temperatures. The values of RL were 0.18, 0.16 and 0.17 at 20, 25 and 30 °C, temperature. All these values confirmed a good adsorption. n and kF [(μg g−1)] are the constants of Freundlich model. These correspond to relative adsorption capacities and sorption intensities, respectively. The intercept and slope of logQt vs logCt (Fig. 4b) correspond to kF and 1/n. The values of kF were 31.55, 29.72 and 28.5 at 20, 25 and 30 °C, temperature. The values of n were 7.25, 6.06 and 5.82 at 20, 25 and 30 °C, temperature, respectively. These values confirmed the applicability of Freundlich model; indicating favorable sorption. Also, these values established low adsorption at high temperature. BT (kJ mol−1) and KT (L μg−1) are constants of heat of sorption and
maximum binding energy. BT and KT were estimated from slope and intercept of Fig. 4c. The values of BT and KT (Table 1) established a good difference in heat of adsorption and good contact between adsorbate and adsorbent. E and qm are average energy and degree of adsorption per mole of pantoprazole. These were estimated from slope and intercept of Fig. 4d. The values of E were ranged from 1.19 to 1.27 kJ/mol (Table 1); signifying physical sorption.

sections.heading: 3.7. Adsorption thermodynamic
sections.text:
The values of free energy, enthalpy and entropywere determined by the following equations.
ΔG0 ¼ −RTlnQ ð10Þ
lnQ ¼ ΔS0=R−ΔH0=RT: ð11Þ
T, R and Q° (Xm) are absolute temperature (K), universal gas constant (8.314 × 10−3 kJ mol−1 K−1) and Langmuir constant. A plot between lnQ° and 1/T was in a straight line (not given herein). The slope and intercept related to ΔS0 ΔH0, respectively. The magnitudes of free energy, enthalpy and entropy are summarized in Table 2. The magnitudes of free energy and enthalpy were negative. Contrarily, value of entropy was positive. These signs obviously signal of sorption impulsive at all the temperatures. Also, negative free energy and enthalpy values suggested exothermic sorption.

sections.heading: 3.8. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
The values of the sorption kineticswere established by the following models.
Pseudo-First-Order Kinetic.
log Qe−Qtð Þ ¼ logQe–k1t=2:303 ð15Þ
Pseudo-Second Order Kinetic Model.
t=Qt ¼ 1=hþ t=Qe ð18Þ
Elovich's Kinetic Model.
Qt ¼ 1=βln αβð Þ þ 1=βlnt: ð19Þ
The equilibrium rate constant [k1] was determined from slope of a graph between log(Qe-Qt) and t (Fig. 5a). Pseudo-first order rate constant and regression coefficient (R2)were 0.10 (min−1) and 0.968; indicating the applicability of pseudo first order kinetics. The theoretical and experimental values of amounts adsorbed were 43.65 and 44.5 μg g−1. The only difference is 1.91%,which close to each other. This examination also supported the applicability of pseudo-first order kineticmodel. Furthermore, pseudo-second order kinetic model was also used to the experimental data to see the exact kinetics. The values of initial (h) and overall rate (k2) were 6.06 and 0.22 (Fig. 5b). The difference between theoretical and experimental amounts adsorbed was 18.30%. This is higher difference in comparison to pseudo-first order kinetic model. Therefore, pseudo-second order kinetic model was not applicable to the experimental data.
α (μg g−1 min−1) and β (μg g−1 min−1) belong to adsorption and desorption processes (Eq. 19). The values of α and β were 17.50 and 0.074 (Table 3). These values indicated adsorption process stronger than desorption process. The value of regression coefficient was 0.949 confirming the utility of Elovich's kinetic model.

sections.heading: 3.9. Adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
The adsorption mechanism was determined by using the following equations.
Intraparticle Diffusion Kinetic Model.
Qt ¼ kipdt05 ð20Þ
Liquid Film Diffusion Kinetic Model.
ln 1−Fð Þ ¼ −kfdt: ð21Þ
The sorption of pantoprazole to adsorption siteswas estimated by 20 equations (Qt vs t0.5). The rate constantwas 7.58 μg g−1min−0.5. The intercept and regression coefficient were 1.0 and 0.989 (Table 3). The graph line did not pass via the origin; indicating non-applicability of intra-particle diffusion model. Kfd and F = Qt / Qe is a film diffusion
rate coefficient and fractional attainment of equilibrium. Kfd and intercept values were 0.6 and 0.2 (Table 3). These values indicated that sorptionwas occurred via diffusion process. A straight line of graph between ln(1-F) and t deviated by only 0.02 value; representing the closeness to the origin. This divergence might be owing to high stirring contact time (in batch experiments) and discrepancy between rates of mass transfer in starting and last stages. Such types of deviations are also reported by other researchers [25–27]. Henceforth, sorption of pantoprazole was considered by liquid film diffusion mechanism.

sections.heading: 3.10. Regeneration of composite iron nano adsorbent
sections.text: The economy of composite iron nano adsorbent was determined by regeneration. Therefore, regeneration of composite iron nano adsorbent was carried out using dilute acids including HCl, H2SO4, HNO3. As well, bases such as potassium hydroxides and sodium hydroxide were also tested for regeneration of the sorbent. Also, some buffers viz. acetate, phosphate, citrate etc.were also used for regeneration. After exhaustive experimentations, 0.50 N hydrochloric acidwas the best one. It regenerated composite iron nano adsorbent up to 98% efficiency. The regenerated adsorbent was used up to 8 batch operations with the removal capabilities ranged from 84 to 89%.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: The synthesized composite iron nano adsorbent was successful for the sorption of pantoprazole from water with 89% uptake. The adsorption process is spontaneous and exothermic. The optimized batch variables were 30.0 min., 50 μg L−1, 7.0, 1.0 g L−1 and 25.0 °C as contact time, concentration, pH, adsorbent amount and temperature. The experimental data had followed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin–Radushkevich isotherms. The values of ΔG° were −9.53, −9.57 and−9.62 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures. The magnitudes of ΔH° and ΔS° were −3.39 and 20.19 × 10−3. These values showed adsorption spontaneous at all the temperatures. The adsorption followed pseudo-first-order and liquid film diffusion mechanisms for pantoprazole. The reported adsorption method was speedy, environmentally friendly and economic; as may be used under natural resources water conditions. The adsorption method is competent to work at natural water resources pH with low amount of adsorbent and contact time. Briefly, the adsorption method may be used for the uptake of pantoprazole from any water resource.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: The authors extend their sincere appreciation to the Deanship of Scientific Research at King Saud University for its funding to this Prolific Research Group (PRG-1436-04).
